description: '''Avant-punk''' is a [[punk music]] style characterized by "screeching experimentation", and a term by which critics used to describe the wave of American [[punk band]]s from the 1970s. It originated with the [[New York City|New York]]â€“based rock band [[the Velvet Underground]], while antecedents included early [[the Kinks|Kinks]] and garage band one-shots collected on the ''[[Nuggets (series)|Nuggets]]'' series of compilation albums. According to critic [[Robert Christgau]], between 1966 and 1975, the only notable acts who could be categorized as "avant-punk" were [[The Velvet Underground|the Velvets]], [[The Fugs]], [[MC5]], [[Iggy Pop]] and [[the Stooges]], [[the Modern Lovers]], and the [[New York Dolls]].
